facts.text: Plaintiff owned 79/120th share in Khasra Nos. 494, 495, 496, 497, 1800/501, 1801/501 and 529 in Mauza Faizpur of Batala as per zamabandi of 1943-44.
On October 1, 1943, plaintiff purchased 23/120th share from Devisahai at Rs. 175 per marla, becoming owner of 17/20th share.
Remaining 3/20th share owned by joint Hindu family with Pindidas as Manager, brothers Haveliram Khemchand and Satyapal as members.
Plaintiff approached Pindidas to consolidate holding by purchasing 3/20th share at Rs. 250 per marla.
Contract entered on October 1, 1945 between plaintiff and Pindidas for sale of 3/20th share, Rs. 100 paid as earnest money.
Pindidas failed to execute sale deed.
Plaintiff instituted suit for specific performance against Pindidas and brothers in court of Sub-Judge First Class, Batala.
Appeal to Punjab High Court in R.F.A. No. 219 of 1950; upheld dismissal of specific performance but ordered return of Rs. 100 earnest money.
Pindidas died during High Court appeal; legal representatives substituted.
Courts below found Pindidas entered contract for land in suit and received Rs. 100, but not binding on family due to no necessity or benefit.
Defendants affluent, no necessity for sale.
Pindidas pleaded contract was for other land, no authority over brothers.
Brothers (defendants 2-4, respondents 13-15) denied contract, or if existed, not binding as no benefit or necessity.

legal_issues.text: Whether contract by manager of joint Hindu family for sale of family property binds the family absent legal necessity, specifically if for 'benefit of the estate'.
Whether courts below erred in holding no benefit to family from sale of fractional share at higher price.

petitioner_arguments.text: Sale beneficial to family as fractional 3/20th share impractical to use; converting to money gains; price Rs. 250/marla vs prior Rs. 175/marla.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Manager can sell if prudent owner would for adequate consideration; cited Jagatnarain v. Mathura Das, Sital Prasad Singh v. Ajablal Mander, In re A.T. Vasudevan

petitioner_arguments.text: Benefit of estate not limited to defensive necessity.

respondent_arguments.text: No necessity for sale; family affluent; contract not for benefit of family.
Pindidas had no right to contract on behalf of brothers.
Even if karta, sale not binding without benefit or necessity.

court_reasoning.text: Contract existed for land in suit; but not binding on family as no necessity and no evidence of benefit; no allegation of management difficulty or loss; no plan to invest proceeds profitably.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Benefit depends on facts of each case; fractional share alone insufficient without more.

court_reasoning.text: Precedents like Jagatnarain require prudence as greater than sole owner; here no such circumstances; no consultation with adult brothers.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Adult members resisted, indicating no perceived benefit.

court_reasoning.text: Specific performance discretionary; rightly refused; no claim under s.15 Specific Relief Act for partial performance.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Plaintiff not willing to accept only Pindidas' interest.

holdings.text: Manager's alienation binds family only if for legal necessity or benefit to estate; benefit assessed per facts, requiring prudence and evidence of advantage.
No specific performance as transaction not shown beneficial; discretion exercised against.

precedents_cited.relevance: Benefit to estate not limited to defensive; prudent owner test, but greater prudence for manager.

precedents_cited.case_name: Hanooman Persaud Pandey v. Babooee Munraj Koonweree
precedents_cited.relevance: Examined in context of manager's powers.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sahu Ram Chandra v. Bhup Singh
Palaniappa Chetty v. Sreemath Daivasikamony Pandra Sannadhi
Sital Prasad Singh v. Ajablal Mander
precedents_cited.relevance: Prudent management test; requires adult members' conviction where present.

precedents_cited.case_name: In the matter of A.T. Vasudevan Ors., minors
precedents_cited.relevance: Manager can alienate if beneficial even without necessity; but context of minors.
Benefit not defensive; but evidence required.

statutes_cited.name: Specific Relief Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Partial specific performance possible if plaintiff relinquishes rest; not claimed here.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate granted for appeal to Supreme Court.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed plaintiff's appeal against High Court's refusal of specific performance, upholding that contract not binding on joint family; affirmed return of earnest money by High Court.
outcome.relief_granted: None to plaintiff beyond High Court's order for return of Rs. 100 earnest money.

key_quotes.text: "for a transaction to be regarded as one which is of benefit to the family it need not necessarily be only of a defensive character."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies scope of 'benefit to estate' beyond necessity.

key_quotes.text: "what transaction would be for the benefit of the family must necessarily depend upon the facts of each case."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "the karta of a joint Hindu family being merely a manager and not an absolute owner, the Hindu law has... placed certain limitations upon his power."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes Harries C.J. on karta's prudent limits.
